reviewText: It looks like the first 2 series of Mike hammer with Keach may be never released on DVD, but here are essentially 2 pilots for the series. Clocking in at 96 mins each, they are almost as long as a theatrical release! Good thrillers, good shoot outs, good Mike Hammer narration, classic Mike Hammer!
summary: 2 great made for TV Hammer movies!

reviewText: In MORE THAN MURDER Hammer appears younger than he does in most of the cases presented in the complete series. He takes a tumble for the "weaker sex" and  offers a surprise ending NOT TO BE MISSED. In my opinion, the best of all the cases.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Stacey Keach IS Mike Hammer - end of story.  These two films are great case studies of the classic hard-boiled detective genre.  It would be really fantastic if the original 1980's Mike Hammer TV show could be released on DVD.  These two movies are the "pilot" episodes for that show.  It was not on for very long, but it was a great show.This double feature is a MUST HAVE for fans of the genre.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I loved this series when it was on TV in the 80's and it is still just as entertaining today. My husband and I would watch it with our 9 year old son who was taking saxophone lessons at the time and he learned to play Harlem Nocturne.  It is still one of the greatest jazz songs ever made. I only wish like so many others that they would bring the entire series back on DVD and not just the made for TV movies. Stacy Keach was the best Hammer and I have seen all of the old movies ever made. It's too bad they can't make good programs like this for TV today instead of all the junk that's out there. Like everything else that is a bye-gone era. Too bad!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Tough guy could mean different things. But in these two definitely dated made-for-TV films, "tough guy", aka Mike Hammer, means a guy who always wears a totally out of date fedora and attracts every single hot looking woman who ever lived in the world and beds about 80% of them.OK. Sounds like sour grapes, right? Yeah, maybe. Maybe that wouldn't be so bad--BUT, every single time he gets involved with a hot lookin babe, she dies. And every time one of these hot lookin babes dies, does our "tough guy" hero even show a single tiny ounce of grief? Nah. He's too g*d-d*mn tough for that. About 20 seconds or so after the babe dies, he's smilin' with his friend Pat Chambers or jokin with his hot lookin secretary. Who cares?Yeah, that's realistic. Sure. Uh huh. Remind me to stick "Mike Hammer" in the dictionary where the phrase "tough guy" is listed.[...].

reviewText: Stacy Keach is the best Mike Hammer ever. DVD arrived in great order and on time as promised. I now have 3 years of Mike Hammer and plan to get the rest.

reviewText: This is no doubt a fine "Double Feature" fare. However, I for one will hold out until the 2 later feature-length films, namely "The Return of MS's MH" and "MS' MH: Murder takes All" are released, specifically as part of a QUADRUPLE feature set.

reviewerName: Out Of Your Element Donny "The Noir The Merrier"
reviewText: I recall watching this show when it was first aired, and I still love the strains of "Harlem Nocturne" evoking the rains-spattered streets of Philip Marlowe and the darkened alleyways of Mike Hammer.  Stacey Keach plays the private dick with his tongue firmly pressed in his cheek, while still radiating enough gravitas to help you suspend disbelief.  These made-for-TV movies are fun, sometimes bordering on pastiche, but it's the way I like to remember Mike Hammer; no, he's not Marlowe, nor is he intended to be--but if the watchers can enter these films with a smile rather than a snarl, they'll find some fun here.

reviewText: Great single program, if you like  Mike Hammer it is well worth  a look.  Stacey Keach is a great actor and is the right actor to play Mike Hammer

reviewText: Why is it that when I think of Velda I think of Lindsey Bloom as Velda?  How many of the series did Lindsey play Velda?These two shows are much better than the 90s version filmed in Ventura, CA., although that series is entertainingand better than most TV shows today in the 21st century.  Why can't we get the rest of the 1980s series?Anyway, this is well worth the price.  I think it is all explained well enough in promotional so I won't go into it.I'll just say I think you'll enjoy it.  I especially enjoyed the one with Lindsey Bloom.  To me she is the same thingto Velda as Stacy Keach is to Mike Hammer--the quintessential duo.  Nobody else even comes close.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ayn Rand mentions Mickey Spillane as having great literary potential, but though Mr. Spillane delves into the innermost being of Mike Hammer, Mr. Spillane had no interest in literary greatness.  His admitted interest?  Earning sufficient for a 'hang loose' good life.  Mr. Spillane understands man's (and woman's) wants.  Stacy Keach understands Mike Hammer, the Private Investigator often caught up in murder, mayhem and mercenary thought. Spillane, Hammer, and Keach present life as it is; filled with givers and takers.  S. H. and K. aim to make takers pay.If you want to more fully understand Mike Hammer, read Spillane's novels.  If you want visual as well as mental entertainment, 'More Than Murder' and 'Murder Me, Murder You'  will satisfy and allow something left-over for you to ponder.  Spillane, Hammer, and Keach.  A perfect trio.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Both of these movies star Stacy Keach as Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer - "Murder Me, Murder You" (1983) and "More Than Murder" (1984). I am a big Spillane fan and I enjoy Stack Keach as Mike Hammer. He enjoys playing the character and it shows Highly recommended!!SBJ
Title: N/A

reviewText: These two Mike Hammer movies starring Stacy Keech are bubble gum for adults. Mike Hammer is surrounded by voluptuous women while making hilarious wisecracks via voice over narration. The plots really don't matter. Stacy Keech swaggers into one situation after another surrounded by women, and one in particular is literally dropped in his lap while she delivers his lunch. How is that for service? Keech should have been a stand up comedian, as his voice over comments are priceless. All you can do while watching these movies, is to envy the Mike Hammer character, as the entire female species is on the prowl for him, and Hammer doesn't put up a fight. No one but Stacy Keech could play this role, and any other actor who would dare try would pale in comparison.
Title: N/A
